Hi,
	I have use this approach (briefly) for an unrelated type of graph.

	There's a few problems:

1) there's no guarantee that there _is_ an internally consistent layout for 
a set of desired node<->node distances.  Some sets of distances are 
inherently inconsistent (e.g. if A<->B = 1 and B<->C = 1 and A<->C = 3 -- I 
believe with complex ordinates you can cover this...?).  Others can only be 
guaranteed to lay out in N - 1 dimensions.

That need not be too much of a problem, you could usually get a 
"reasonable" layout, and your original expression in terms of attractions 
and repulsions, rather than distances, already acknowledges this, however:

2) topological problems can wipe you out -- e.g. it can easily be the case 
that the required topology of connections, if squashed into 2D, contains so 
many unavoidable line-crossings that it breaks the diagram.  In this case 
what you see is two unconnected groups of nodes get forced into close 
proximity because (i) some edge in group1 has cross an edge in group 2, but 
(ii) the radii of the two groups are too large for them to be kept apart if 
both those edges are present

3) initial layout can be irresolvable --  if A is attracted to B but is 
initially positioned on the far side of some heavily-interconnected block 
of nodes, then the attractive force of A and B may be unable to force A to 
pass through the block (or worse enough to drag it into the block but not 
out the far side)

You can play with the relative force strengths to improve this a bit, but 
generally it can only go so far because as a technique it's not really 
considering the factors a human wants in the diagram.  It works really well if:

1) fairly few edges
2) topology fits in 2D
3) can start with a layout which respects topology

And to answer the question in another post, yes it can be CPU 
intensive.  There's a dependence on M (number of edges) and N^2 (number of 
nodes, squared) but worse, walking such a system down hill can require 
millions of iterations (better optimization routines can be used, but can 
get unstable on steep hillsides).  A Monte Carlo approach might be better 
able to step out of start-up glitches -- you almost need a GA to do the 
layout...

The basic force-field approach can be worth experimenting with, but it's 
not a "magic" fix, and tinkering with it can eat up days of programmer time...

	Ian B
